newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Oct 1.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Oct 1.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

In a strong show of support for continued assistance for the car and textile industries, Prime Minister John Howard said yesterday that Australia would not cut its tariffs further unless Asian countries did the same. Howard declared he believed in lower tariffs, but it was legitimate to argue that Australian companies had problems competing against highly protected Asian firms. Page 1.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants' national professional standards committee has found errors in more than half the 138 annual reports it recently reviewed and queried the company auditors over 25 percent of the reports it saw. The committee found that disciplinary action was required for a number of auditors, who had been tripped up by the huge amount of detail required by new Corporations Law and accounting standards requirements. Page 3.

According to a survey released by the Australian Supermarket Institute in Sydney yesterday, Australian consumers are now increasingly likely to shop on any day of the week, rather than a late night shopping day and Australians are spending more on household groceries, with an average A$112 being spent a week. Page 4.

Following comments by Chief Justice of Australia Gerard Brennan about the delays and expense associated with the court system, Federal Attorney-General Daryl Williams said yesterday that a series of reforms were being implemented in federal courts which made greater use of techniques in line with those suggested by the Chief Justice. Page 4.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Speaking at the Cities of Asia-Pacific Conference in Brisbane yesterday, Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer warned that Independent MP Pauline Hanson's attacks on Asian immigration could damage Australia's economic interests and export future. He said Hanson's comments received a considerable amount of coverage in Asia which is not "helpful". Page 1.

Alleged Port Arthur gunman Martin Bryant made his first public appearance yesterday to answer the charges arising from the massacre at Port Arthur in Tasmania in April. Appearing before the Hobart Supreme Court, Bryant pleaded not guilty to all 72 charges including 32 charges of murder, and will go on trial on November 19. Page 1.

Speaking before the release yesterday of figures showing a current account deficit of just A$1.33 billion for August, Prime Minister John Howard said the path was set for lower interest rates, while the Opposition demanded an immediate cut in rates, intensifying pressure on Reserve Bank Governor Ian Macfarlane. Page 1.

Federal Health Minister Michael Wooldridge admitted on ABC radio yesterday that the government had been forced to consider re-introducing quotas on foreign doctors allowed to practice in this country in response to a backlash over its budget decision to restrct GP numbers. Page 3.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

From today, a new regulation change means any taxi driver who carries a baby without a baby capsule or baby seat will face a A$103 fine and the loss of three points on their licence. The regulation will bring taxis in line with private vehicles by lifting an exemption which has allowed parents to carry babies on their laps while travelling in taxis. Page 1.

Dr Philip Nitschke, the doctor at the centre of the voluntary euthanasia debate in the Northern Territory and who last week assisted a Darwin cancer patient to end his life using the territory's landmark euthanasia law, is facing a coronial inquest into the deaths of two heroin addicted patients whose bodies were found to contain methadone. Page 3.

Delivering a paper to the annual conference of the International Association of Civilian Oversight of Law Enforcement in Virginia, Police Royal Commissioner Justice James Wood attacked the media for contributing to police corruption. He also said the Independent Commission Against Corruption was largely ineffectual. Page 3.

A court heard yesterday that former Australian heavyweight boxing champion Dean Waters fatally shot his stepmother's lover, saying he succumbed to months of pressure and mental harassment from his father Cec that the man "had to die", but decided at the last minute not to kill his stepmother. Page 3.
THE AGE

After yesterday quietly pleading not guilty to all 72 charges relating to the Port Arthur shootings, Australia's worst mass killing in modern times, Martin Bryant will go to trial in November with no indication of his defence to the charges, including 35 of murder. Page A1.

Police are seeking legal advice on whether the editors of Rabelais, the La Trobe University student magazine, have committed an offence by publishing a photograph of Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett's face framed in the cross hairs of a gun sight with the caption: "Is death good enough for this man?". Page A1.

Dr Philip Nitschke, the Northern Territory doctor who last week assisted Darwin cancer sufferer Robert Dent to end his life using the territory's euthanasia law, is facing an inquest on two heroin-addicted bodies that were found to contain methadone, more than a year after the first man died. Page A1.

Monash University employee Sheena Maokhamphiou, who allegedly suffered from a pathological gambling disorder and who stole overseas students' fees totalling nearly A$78,000 to support her habit, will spend her 24th birthday today serving the first day of 14-month jail sentence. Page A3.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
